b'b" +1 I\'d also like to raise another issue related to this: . I\'m not sure if this has been discussed in regards to other icons. I personally think the current and icons need to have spacing to the right build into the glyph itself. Imagine toggling between off state. You\'d use and as the two states. The icon would then jump inside of the button because of different widths (assuming they\'d be centered inside of the button). To sum it up: all three (or then four) volume icons should have the same width. When stacking them on top of each other the speakers should align. b'b" There are two conflicting use cases — (1) icons are redundant with words and should not be pronounced; (2) icons are used alone and should be pronounced. In the latter case the name of the icon is frequently not the right pronunciation. For example
column11: an X icon might be used for close
column12: cancel
column13: delete
column14: or no. For that reason
column15: I don\'t think adding attributes across the board is the right solution. But a solution for (1) should not preclude the developer from adding attributes for case (2). I think the best solution is to have a simple way to add to all icons. I can imagine doing this by adding with some appropriate CSS but I don\'t think that CSS would be very performant. The other alternative is to have a different CSS file with added. Maybe someone else can suggest a way of doing this more elegantly and efficiently."'

column11: why is this closed? The icon-save indicates to save a single file as indicated with a single floppy disk. A save all operation is in most cases indicated with two or three stacked disks. This is really handy for applications where multiple files can be opened and modified at the same time. It is also a very commonly used metaphor in almost all editing applications. I definitely would love to see a dedicated icon for it.'"

Sometimes bloggers use Creative Commons licenses in their posts and using an icon to illustrate that would be just a perfect thing.'"
b'b\' I have to agree with the rest of the crowd that CC icons aren\\\'t a narrow focus. To me
column11: an example of narrow focus are game controller button icons. A series of icons representing the buttons of all gamepad controllers would be very specific. Only video game sites that illustrating specific commands would need the approved icon for Left Bumper or "Option" button. Very narrow in focus and application. Creative Commons on the other hand applies to a large amount of media in a large amount of contexts. Just as \\xe2\\x84\\xa2 or \\xc2\\xae can be applied to any work
column12: Creative Commons licenses have the same scope.\''

column11: with the intention to move things forward: Following the [rules for requesting icons]url Rule 2
column12:
!specific":  CC icons are widely used in many fields, as @hamishcampbell (and others) explained with examples. See url Rule 3, "+1":  searching the page for "+1" gives 57 matches  it is the [12th most commented issue]url  out of 2.469 open onesRule 4, "single icon":  this is a request for several icons, however CC icons are used together, side by side, to form a single "complex" icon, depending on the license variation. See url if it would really help, this request can easily be split into several requestsRule 5: CC icons are already created, provided by the CC organization, as a [TTF font]url so there is no design nor font forging work to do.  In addition, @mattl offered help as Tech Lead at CC, see url  ## Next step My understanding is that the next step is a "go" or "no go" decision from the Font Awesome project leaders. In case of positive answer, then would come the integration work.\''

b"b' suggestion: add GSUB rules for universal substitutions'"
b'b\' I\\\'d like to suggest adding GSUB rules for all the entities in your font
column11: so that typing the word "icon-flickr-sign"
column12: for instance
column13: is substituted with the icon for it from the private use area by intelligent font engines. That way the font can be deployed in a much wider context
column14: and you don\\\'t have to write PUA codepoints yourself
column15: the font will make sure the right thing happens.\''

column10: b'b" I\'m not following. Is GSUB a Ruby thing?"'

column11: It\\\'s an OpenType font thing
column12: and fonts have been able to pull off this trick for a while (you just rarely hear about it
column13: because most of the time it\\\'s for things you don\\\'t really think about
column14: like character substitution in arabian writing so the right letters are used at different positions in a word). You can set up a GSUB table ("global substitution") that is the fancier version of ligatures tables. Instead of blindly turning multiple letters
column15: like f+f
column16: into single other letters
column17: like the ff ligature
column18: you can use the GSUB table to make the font replace specific sequences of unicode with other sequences of unicode instead (of any length). This means that things like icon replacements become really cool: we can leave it to the font entirely
column19: and we never have to actually use a character map or a lookup page to find the right icon to copy-paste: the font\\\'ll do it for us as long as we type the right words.  For instance
column20: you could have a GSUB rule that says "if I am used to render the character sequence \\\'icon-flickr-sign\\\' then replace that string with the Private Use Area glyph 17 and render that instead". Now all we have to do is apply the font to a div
column21: and if it contains the word "icon-flickr-sign"
column22: bam! icon. Without any hassle. OSX
column23: Windows and _n_x all understand OpenType fonts
column24: and all browsers do too (within the limitations of their implementation of webfonts of course
column26: so no worries there (note that both .ttf and .otf are OpenType fonts
column27: they follow the same spec but use different outline vector procedures
column28: so despite the extension suggesting that the .ttf is a TrueType font
column29: it\\\'s actually an OpenType font with TrueType outlines
column30: supporting all the goodness OpenType fonts let us exploit =) For an example of how awesome this is
column31: check out the FF Chartwell font
column32: url  which uses OpenType features to turn normally typed numbers into full blown charts. Simply by letting the font do its thing
column33: rather than using a scripting language or charting library.\''

column11: I\'ll want to pick your brain about this offline. I\'m really a font amateur
column12: so help is definitely appreciated. :) Drop me an email."'

column10: b"b' So symbolset does something like:  Could we do that with FontAwesome?  Might look like:  '"
b'b\' the idea of the text already encoding what it is means that you\\\'d do something like with the CSS specifying that the font-family for \\\'fontawesome-icon\\\' is fontawesome
column11: and then let GSUB take care of it. The font engine sees the string "closed eye"
column12: and asks the font "do you have a rule for this sequence of unicode points?" the font goes "yep
column13: this long sequence actually maps to ..."
column14: and the engine replaces the text with the replacement before rendering it. No extra classes to indicate "what" to put in its place
column15: the text itself is already the indicator =)\''

this is not a request to _replace_ the current classes
column12: it\'s a request to _add_ GSUB rules. The worst implementation would be to add GSUB rules and then ditch the icon classes
column13: that would make no sense
column14: we\'d lose an incredibly valuable way to use icons in places where using full word substitution is inappropriate. In your example case
column15: you\'d still have the option to just go (I know font-awesome likes to use the element
column16: but if you want to do proper content
column17: don\'t; you\'re not writing italicised text. Using real sematic markup helps address the issue that screen readers will run into
column18: especially if accompanied by the appropriate ARIA role)."'

column10: b"b' Well as long as people were able to properly correlate the glyphs to the words they needed to produce them
column11: then why would there be a problem with translations? For example
column12: you cannot go as it stands now and still get the closed eye icon.'"

column11: but for screen readers
column12: used by a surprisingly large number of people on the web as a whole
column13: it matters a lot. As such
column14: if your site has a non-trivial number of users with accessibility needs (and that doesn\\\'t just cover blind people
column15: but also people with sight issues or reading impairments such as dyslexia or aphasia
column16: as well as any people who simply feel they benefit from having a screen reader turned on while they\\\'re also browsing the web "normally")
column17: you need to take @Arkkimaagi\\\'s objection into account: using full word substitution is not a good idea there
column18: whereas will still work perfectly fine; icons will get "read out" properly
column19: in the expected language
column20: while visually users will be presented with only the icon
column21: using CSS to hide the span\\\'s textContent.\''

column11: unless the font fails to load for some unseen network reason
column12: then the replaced text will never be shown to the end user anyways. So the developer is the only one that needs to know the icon replacement ligatures.'"

column11: but not moreso than other text that relies on ligatures (which is quite a lot of text that\'s styled with good webfonts via Typekit etc.). It depends a little on how the CSS resolves if the stylesheet loads first
column12: with time to set up a font listener on the FontAwesome resources before those get loaded in (so not first
column13: then rest of CSS)
column14: then CSS can kick in before the content starts to show up
column15: with correctional CSS kicking in once the font resource is properly available
column16: and you shouldn\'t get FOUT-style behaviour (provided the CSS is well written
column17: of course)"'

column10: b'b\' Another problem I can see with implementing this is when there are variants of an icon. One example is Facebook
column11: there are currently 3 different icons for that
column12: so people would need some way of specifying which one is used without having to add "non-semantic" text
column13: i.e. the only text that should be contained in the tag is "facebook"
column14: without "-official" or "-square".\''

column10: b'b\' Why? If you need the right icon
column11: you want precision. In the same way you\\\'d need something like right now
column12: you would use "facebook-square" and done? Remember: we\\\'re dealing with icons
column13: so the absolute first question you need to ask is "which markup am I using
column14: based on the role this icon plays". If the icon is eye candy only
column15: then it doesn\\\'t matter in the slightest what the text is
column16: because no one is going to see that text (only the subtituted icon) and screen readers should absolutely not read them out (for instance
column17: a facebook icon next to a link to a facebook article should not exist as far as a screen reader is concerned. It contributes nothing). In this case (and why I requested GSUB rules) it\\\'s a matter of ease-of-maintenance. On the other hand
column18: if your icon is heavily semantic
column19: you need probably need to stop and ask yourself why you\\\'re using an icon at all. If the text matter to readers
column20: why are you removing that text and replacing it with a picture that not everyone is going to be able to easily understand
column21: or make out? This is an important UI question. By asking the right question before using Font-Awesome
column22: but really _any_ icon solution
column23: you won\\\'t run into this problem. It\\\'s a symptom of a premature implementation.\''

column10: b"b' How I solved my issue with out-of-center rotation of icon font:There were several issues I had to resolve:  1. size of icon: it has to be whole px size (e.g. font-size:small; makes my icon 17.5px so center is not absolute center for transformation)  2. defining display: block on icon level makes it center correctly in the middle of the parent div  3. defining exact square size of parent div (in my case button) and fixed padding made it center correctly  4. adding any text-shadow will change the size of the inner icon so it will be out of the center. Trick is to change the hover style to be the same shadow with color same as background in my case So here is the code: HTML: and finally JQuery for switching rotate class url  '"

If FA is a font icon set for bootstrap, then it _should_ work out of the box by simply replacing the link to the font file. For me, that is not out of the box. but I said:tagliala said:If you want override old bootstrap stuff (bootstrap 2.x), you needs universal selectors in any case, isn\\\'t it?That is because **they** used universal selectors instead of a base class, like "icon". column11: although the bootstrap included :  @font-face {  font-family: \'Glyphicons Halflings\';  src: url(\'......./bootstrap-3/-halflings-\');  src: url(\'......../bootstrap-3/-halflings-?#iefix\')    format(\'embedded-opentype\')
column12: url(\'....../bootstrap-3/-halflings-\') format(\'woff\')
column13: url(\'....../bootstrap-3/-halflings-\') format(\'truetype\')
column14: url(\'......../bootstrap-3/-halflings-#glyphicons-halflingsregular\')    format(\'svg\');}"'

column10: b'b" Only reason that this _seems_ to work for you
column11: is that including the font-face definition in an earlier location in your CSS in **»this one specific occasion«** only
column12: causes the font to finish loading before IE\'s first crack at rendering the page. Thus you avoid the issue with IE not repainting pseudo-elements
column13: because they\'re already completely rendered as they should be _on first paint_. However
column14: you have absolutely zero control over all the timing conditions involved and thus **zero** guarantee that this will work correctly everywhere on all connections for everyone."'

column12: I just wanted to mention that we work really hard to respect brand guidelines and keep things as up to date as possible. Last time Instagram had a new logo
column13: we had a new version of Font Awesome within a day. We\'ve also worked with companies directly around making minor tweaks where we\'d missed something. We care deeply about this.  As far as the Fedora logo goes
column14: we\'ll do whatever Red Hat / Fedora deems best. We\'d really prefer not to remove the logo entirely
column15: as this would be a breaking change. Not to mention that we\'ve never had to remove a logo from Font Awesome ever before
column16: so there\'d be a good bit of development work needed to take care of this.  Is there any chance there\'s a single-color version of the Fedora logo that works for you all until your larger work on a new version?"'

column11: but I need to be the bag guy here. That icon is really not acceptable. I respectfully request you go back to your design team and have them take another pass.  The purpose of an icon is to distinguish something in the simplest form possible that can be recognized at a magnitude of different sizes. The most common favicon size is 16px x 16px
column12: which all those diagonal lines get completely lost at. In Material Design
column13: the icon needs to be recognizable at 24dp
column14: which this icon simply cannot satisfy. In fact
column15: in can\'t even satisfy 48dp.  Here is an example: ![image]url  Please reconsider this."'

column13: but in my experience that never works as well because the combined icons behave less consistently than a purpose-made set. The biggest hurdle I\'ve found with trying to add or supplement the FA with file type icons from another font is that I haven\'t found one that\'s 14px-based. Trying to add the Font Awesome icons
column14: or a selection of them
column15: to a new font with 16px-based file type icons from another font leads to inconsistent alignments in positioning and of course the different optimal sizes create their own issues. column11: this is my own personal views: That FAQ link no longer works
column12: but I believe this is the relevant part:So its not true to say
column13:
SIL OFL 1.1 is GPL compatible" what you mean is, "SIL OFL 1.1 fonts can be distributed alongside a GPL program, where any font can be subtituted and the program will work the same"  The OFL is **not** GPL compatible, you can not integrate an OFL work into a GPL work to create a combined work. But this is never done in practice. Its even hard for me to think up theoretical ways to do it.\''
Font-Awesome	1124	closed	3	kreynen	2013-05-20 09:18:20	1191.63			+1	b'b" Someone just request this project be whitelisted to be included with a Drupal distribution url  Drupal\'s policies about what can be packaged on together on  require GPLv2 compatibility.  I am not a lawyer either, but when I reviewed this request to see if OFL was compatible with both GPLv2 and GPLv3 I came to the same conclusion as @davelab6.  **OFL is NOT GPL compatible at all.**  I can find several references saying it is not GPL compatible and nothing (other than Font Awesome project) saying that it is. OFL is listed in the Fonts section of url  NOT the url  section. url  (unfortunately uncited)If the font was truly GPL compatible it would have the same issue as GPL licensed fonts and may unintentionally lead to documents created using the font be required to also be GPL.  This is why the GPL+FE was created... url The Open Font Library does a decent job of defining the different licenses fonts can use and the licenses actually being used. url url  For this to be packaged with a Drupal distribution using a license currently used by fonts, the font itself it would have to be licensed as MIT and (possibly?) GPLv2+FE."'

Font-Awesome	1124	closed	5	hswong3i	2013-05-20 09:18:20	636.17	+1			b'b\' After some basic study I would like to suggest dual license with OFL and GPLv2+FE for fonts file. some example and founding:Case as url  (OFL + GPLv3) may not be a good idea since some project (e.g. Drupal, where I am coming from) are still GPLv2 ONLYurl  also in GPLv3 so again not a good idea...url  also GPLv3...WELL!! Finally a good example for OFL + GPLv2+FE url ~:/ and url ~) As a Drupal developer personally I am very sorry about the strict GPLv2 policy that now we are enforcing which make a trouble to other else FOSS project; but this strict GPLv2 policy also encourage numbers of contributor to contribute their work to public (24,496 Modules + 1,878 Themes + 710 Distributions + 30,126 Developers). Please kindly consider "adding" GPLv2+FE together with OFL, therefore we can safely include this awesome project into Drupal, as originally stated: url \''
Font-Awesome	1124	closed	6	davelab6	2013-05-20 09:18:20	183.42			+1	b'b" I think just OFL is fine; that it isn\'t GPL compatible isn\'t relevant because Drupal is doing aggregate distribution of the font. \\xc2\\xa72 of the GPLv2 says, "'
Font-Awesome	1124	closed	7	kreynen	2013-05-20 09:18:20	486.4	+1			b'b\' @davelab6  I think we actually agree on the licensing issues.  GPL compatibility is only relevant because Drupal demands everything be licensed w/ GPLv2 or a license the FSF agrees is GPLv2 compatible.  Bundling OFL w/ GPLv2 isn\\\'t a GPL issue, it\\\'s a Drupal issue.  The GPLv2 or later license Drupal uses allows someone to bundle Drupal with a GPLv3 license on Github and include Font-Awesome (OFL 1.1) and Bootstrap (Apache 2.0). **They just can\\\'t do it on .**  Drupal is the reason Bootstrap is moving to an MIT license w/ the 3.1 release.  url  Like @hswong3i, I have to apologize for how ridiculous this must seem to other projects.  We are like the angry old folks telling kids to get off our lawn with their new fangled licenses.  I will make the case to allow OFL and licenses w/ the +FE exception when we make the change to GPLv3 for Drupal distributions, but right now MIT is the only license used with fonts that we would approve packaging with a distribution on . My reason for posting wasn\\\'t to get Font-Awesome to change it\\\'s license, but to agree that the "GPL compatible" claim isn\\\'t accurate.  \''

column10: b'b\' That is why I like "GPL friendly" over "GPL compatible". Unfortunately Wordpress often defers to Drupal when dealing with GPL url  WordPress is making the same confusing "GPL compatible" claim about the font licenses they allow.  The links to the GNU and Fedora lists are more carefully worded. url  I\\\'ve started url If you\\\'d like to provide feedback from the perspective of a font that currently can\\\'t be included because of the licensing issues
column11: we\\\'d welcome it.  Drupal is slow to move on issues like this because most "open source" users don\\\'t understand the differences in the licenses and attempts to discuss it openly often leads to a lot of bikeshedding. There are a growing number of people who understand these licensing issues in the Drupal community
column12: but we\\\'re a large community so change takes time.  Please work with us.  I know that Drupal\\\'s views on an MIT only license vs. dual  only changed when JQuery took the advice of the FSF and moved back to MIT only license url In full disclosure... yes
column13: Drupal had pushed JQuery to use dual license. All I can do is apologize for Drupal\\\'s current licensing policies and ask you to help us make the case to change them.  \''

column10: b'b\' @tagliala Again... I\\\'m not a lawyer and this is getting dangerously close to legal advice.  IMHO
column11:
friendly" is a much better description of the relationship between OFL licensed resources and GPL code.  It might be worth reaching out to the Free Software Foundation for true legal advice.  If you ask a lawyer who isn\\\'t a FOSS advocate, they\\\'ll probably tell you to remove the compatibility claim completely.  Every time I get into one of this discussions, I\\\'m less surprised by resources licensed with the WTFPL license url That license is not recommended, but recognized by the FSF as GPL compatible.  It\\\'s a way for people to give their work away while at the same time complain about how complicated it is to give it away.\''
Font-Awesome	1124	closed	19	tagliala	2013-05-20 09:18:20	153.93		+1		b"b' just sent an email to FSF. I will let you know :)'

Thanks for writing to the FSF.  Please see response below:It is OK to distribute fonts licensed under the terms of the SIL OFL 1.1  _alongside_ a GPL licensed work. What we mean by "alongside" is that the font andthe program would be considered "separate works" under the terms of the GNU GPL
column12: because they aren\\\'t combined in any way
column13: but simply aggregated. It is often the casethat a program (such as a word processor) can make use of makes use of a particularfont without the font being considered part of the Program or the font and programbeing considered a single combined work. It is of course possible that you could create a combined work depending on howimplementation is done. Such cases should be avoided with works licensed under theGNU GPL
column14: because the SIL OFL 1.1 is incompatible with the GNU GPL. This is becauseSection 5 of SIL OFL 1.1 has the following requirement that is incompatible with theterms of the GNU GPL: "The Font Software
column15: modified or unmodified
column16: in part or inwhole
column17: must be distributed entirely under this license
column18: and must not be distributedunder any other license." This is incompatible with the terms of the GNU GPL
column19: because the GNU GPL has a similar statement that requires the entire work to beunder the terms of the GNU GPL.I hope that helps. Regards

b'b" The OFL isn\'t considered a [GPL-compatible free software license]url  because it isn\'t a software license at all. However
column11: it allows bundling the fonts with software
column12: and in fact requires doing so if the fonts are sold. [Here\'s the FSF\'s take on it:]url This is supported by the text of the license itself [(SIL Open Font License version 1.1)]url  : (Emphasis added.) So there shouldn\'t be a problem using OFL-licensed fonts in software
column13: including software that\'s GPL-licensed.  But even then
column14: an OFL-licensed font does not become GPL-licensed:(Emphasis added.) So even in GPL software
column15: the OFL still applies to the font itself. The GPL does not."'

column10: b'b" This is true as long as the GPL software can use any font
column11: and is justconfigured to use a particular (OFL) font. If there was some tightintegration between the program and the font
column12: it might switch from\'aggregate distribution\' of 2 separate works
column13: the program and the font
column14: into a \'derivative (combined) work\'"'

column10: b'b" I think all you\'d have to do is specify
column11: in the  notice
column12: that the software is GPL-licensed but a separate license applies to the OFL-licensed fonts."'

column10: b'b" No not really. It is not a specific icon
column11: like a layer icon from the referenced issue. It\'s more related to icon stacking. A common use case. You are creating a user-management for your application. So you have a user icon for that. Now for the button to add a user
column12: you may use the user icon and overlay it with an additional icon (like a plus sign) to indicate the add behavior. Same for removing. Maybe a little pen as an overlay to indicate edit behavior. From the fabulous silk icons: url This would be user_
column13: user_
column14: user_For silk there is a icon for each of these use cases
column15: however the plus icons are repeatedly overlayed over various other icons and filename suffix with _add
column16: _delete
column17: _edit etc. In reality you only need the user icon plus the various overlays and you can combine them in css. Understandable now?"'

fa-circle fa-inverse" and "fa-plus-circle" in order to have the same result than a "add database" icon, such as: The idea is the following:1) Stack "fa-circle fa-inverse" with "fa-plus-circle" slightly smaller, so that the fa-circle will appears as a surround of fa-plus-circle.2) Stack "fa-database" big-size, with the first stacked icons small size3) Position the first stacked icons group in the bottom-rigth-corner. The idea is then to decline the database icon fa-database in a whole set: add-database, remove-database, database-warning, database-error, refresh-database, download-database, etc... Or maybe another approach, if it\\\'s not possible to stack groups of icons and groups of stacked icons, add a css style in order to create a surrounding on an icon (which will fill by the way the inner part of the icon), something like:"fa fa-plus-circle text-success fa-surround fa-surround-inverse fa-stack-bottom-right"which then would be used in the current stacked, extended with the positioning to be defined.The example would produce something like a green plus-circle surrounded (fa-surround) with black (fa-surround-inverse). b'b" # Recap  There are many proposals to approach this issue. Since the target is to stack **any** icon on **any** icon
column11: some approaches will not work and others will have drawbacks. No silver bullets here at the moment.  Said so
column12: please do not +1 this request: take a look at this comment and pick up the solution that will better fit your needs ## Approach 2: Automagically make new icons  **:arrow_right: url ### Pros: 1. Transparency 2. (Almost) Pixel perfect 3. Simple markup ( )  ### Cons: 1. Customization requires skills and time 2. Huge icon and stylesheet file size. 3. Not as good as handmade icons   ## Approach 3: Stack with text shadow  **:arrow_right: url  **:arrow_right: #5027**  ### Pros: 1. Transparency  ### Cons: 1. No pixel perfection at 14px 2. No support for IE8 **and** IE9 url  3. Complex markup (stack) 4. Non-transparent contours around overlay icon   ## Approach 4: Stack with badges  **:arrow_right: url ### Pros: 1. Pixel perfect  ### Cons: 1. No transparency 2. Poor IE8 support 3. Can\'t stack any icon on any icon 4. Very complex markup (stack with more than 2 icons)  **Note: This approach will not solve this issue (you can\'t actually stack any icon on any icon)**   ## Approach 5: SVG cut  **:arrow_right: url ### Pros: 1. Transparency 2. Will actually stack any icon on any icon including a cut-out as described here: url ### Cons: 1. No pixel perfection 2. Poor browser support 3. Ugly rendering 4. Extremely complex markup "'

Show tested and highly rated combinations" or "Show all combinations".  Perhaps the second one is the default (only the bold and adventurous users dare to use the last one).4. Some icon overlays could have its own custom logic, and even be exclusively overlays.  Some examples: Slashed icons, as mentioned by @tagliala and implemented by @nyon "Remote" overlay (little wi-fi-like waves at the corner).  Imagine mixing it with icons like file, play, database, camera, user, phone, print, hdd, headphones, etc. "Broken" icons.  I realize that this might be a lot harder to implement, but it could still work with some icons (perhaps intersect a zig-zag line along the vertical axis, slightly rotate the right half). column10: b'b" @nyon feel free to use any or all parts of the mockup I made.  Here\'s the source: url "'
b'b\' Can actions be defined like unicode non-space characters? url  All Action would need a common outline and place
column11: say a circle.  This would reduce the possible icons from **icons x actions** to **(icons+iconswithaction) + (actions x 2)** Actions would be defined as normal "icon glyph" for html overlayand as a combining character glyph. So the content actually is a combined character Maybe the creation for the "withaction" glyphs could be automated with a method nyon uses...\''
but is it possible to do subtractive operations with these characters? I guess
column12: it isn\'t. The problem with having actions combined with normal icons is
column13: that we cannot automatically create transparent outlines. This is why no solution works
column14: which only is able to do additive operations (like CSS overlays or stacking)."'

column11: only combining
column12: subtracting would be a bit overkill in font drawing. This would work only with a common basic shape
column13: like if the actions are drawn like plus-square
column14: minus-square
column15: phone-square
column16: pencil-square (or circle variants) in a smaller variant. And the underlying glyph has a form
column17: with a common cut out for *-square-action.  For calender-*-o
column18: the middle part could be done with combining. Then you could combine these with folder-o and get folder-plus-o
column19: folder-minus-o
column20: folder-times-o folder-image-o variant  (A media folder) would be done with combing the internal part of the file-*-o variants.'"

b'b" @ThomasGreiner Thanks for the clarification. But FWIW
column11: I disagree slightly that ABP is completely neutral on this issue. This blog post:url and this page:url  Contain /descriptions/ of what fanboy-social will do for you. Those descriptions focus on sharing buttons that track you even when you don\'t engage with them. They /don\'t/ make it clear that e.g. social LOGIN buttons will be effected. (yes
column12: whole login buttons disappear: url  I\'d suggest ABP ought to adjust its /descriptions/ of fanboy-social to be more clear. OR
column13: if they\'d rather remain neutral
column14: to stop endorsing it at all. As things stand
column15: I claim that from the perspective of an average ABP user who reads one of those pages
column16: agrees that she doesn\'t like being tracked by Facebook share buttons she doesn\'t engage with
column17: and installs the \'s a BUG that icons and indeed /whole login buttons/ suddenly disappear. I know anecdotally I\'ve had a few users who were confused and frustrated that in some browsers they couldn\'t log in to my website. (I\'ve also emailed the fanboy-social maintainer at @ directly. If people agree this is a bug in fanboy-social
column18: they might consider doing the same.) I don\'t intend to point fingers here. There are probably people who /want/ to block social login buttons
column19: and it makes sense to me for ABP
column20: with some customization
column21: to provide that functionality. I think we just need to tighten up the the messaging so users don\'t get unexpected behavior and these projects don\'t have to play cat and mouse :) IMO the first step there is drawing some distinctions in what /kinds/ of social things you might want to block. My first guess at that is something like (1) only things that track you without you even clicking (2) all share buttons (\'I never want to share so don\'t even ask me\')
column22: but not login buttons (3) anything having anything to do with social

column10: b'b" @Paulmicha AdBlock currently subscribes users to four filter lists by default: EasyList
column11: the primary list of ad-blocking filters that all ad blockers use; AdBlock Custom
column12: which cleans up a few troublesome filters from EasyList and other filters that break specific sites
column13: and adds blocks for ad providers EasyList doesn\'t care about; Acceptable Ads
column14: which blocks intrusive
column15: annoying ads while allowing ads that promise to be good (how faithfully some ads adhere to the AA guidelines is up for debate); and the Adblock Warning Removal list
column16: which prevents you from seeing warnings to disable your ad blocker on some sites. We also include some lists that are available by selection but are not enabled by default. Among them is Fanboy\'s Annoyances
column17: which includes Fanboy\'s Social list. That\'s the one that\'s causing trouble with Font Awesome\'s social media icons. Finally
column18: users can subscribe to any list they like if they know its URL. All of the above is true for ABP as well
column19: with some slight differences. So you see there really isn\'t any way we can prevent this on the extension side. It\'s a filter list issue
column20: and we don\'t maintain the filter lists. I wish we _could_ help! It would make things easier for our users
column21: which is my chief concern."'

column11: such lists are not included by default in AdBlock or Adblock Plus. Also
column12: as mentioned in my previous comment
column13: I\\\'d suggest discussing the scope of this particular filter list with the [EasyList]url  team or alternatively reporting individual issues using the issue reporter in Adblock Plus for Firefox. What Adblock Plus does is recommend certain filter lists by providing its users the ability to easily enable popular features. So if there\\\'s a well-maintained filter list that blocks social media elements without breaking unrelated stuff
column14: feel free to suggest it to be used for the "Remove social media buttons" feature.\''

column10: b'b" **Visio stopped supporting the OTF font format starting at Visio 2003.  Visio will only see TTF fonts.** I tried converting FA 4.3.0 via an online converter
column11: but it didn\'t work.  I also tried using the webfont TTF file
column12: and it still didn\'t work. There is probably something malformed about the original file.  I know that FontForge thinks there are some errors in it.  _As jimlamb commented above
column13: the Ligature Symbols font works
column14: so maybe check out its file structure?_ In any case
column15: I hope you can figure it out.  I think FontAwesome is great -thanks for your hard work!"'

column10: b'b\' I would like to clarify a couple of things just so that we\\\'re all on the same page:The image referenced in url  is the American Sign Language sign for "interpret" and is the most common icon seen in places of public accommodation to indicate that events will be interpreted into and from ASL.The image referenced in my previous post url  is a common sign for "sign" across several European sign languages and was adopted as the sign for "sign" in International . As an icon
column11: it is commonly seen in places of public accommodation to indicate that events will be given in sign language (sometimes via an interpreter
column12: sometimes directly by a sign language user). There are legal reasons for the difference between the usages
column13: largely that deaf people have fewer legal rights to request interpreter services in most European countries than American deaf people do in the US. The point I\\\'m emphasizing here is that the ASL icon is indeed about interpreting
column14: whereas the European-inspired/"more international" icon is about the use of sign language in general
column15: not necessarily via an interpreter. The Font Awesome short codes should reflect these facts.\''

column10: b"b' Restrictive embeddable permission in OTF and TTF variants'"

column11: In both variants the embeddable permissions are set to "printable"(fstype=0004) instead of "installable"(fstype=0000). This causes a bug when the font is served to Internet Explorer 9+: CSS3114: @font-face failed OpenType embedding permission check. Permission must be Installable. I assume this is caused by default settings of used font authoring tool. It can be also fixed by tool like url  during build process. Note: IE9+ behavior is reproduced only when neither woff nor eot variants are served to IE. There are valid use cases for doing so. column10: b'b" @tagliala On browsers rendering with DirectWrite
column11: the default behavior is to allow full subpixel precision rendering of a font at sizes of 21px or greater. And the icons in the font set look _fine_ at those sizes
column12: if occasionally somewhat blurred. This has very little to do with rendering at exact multiples of 14px. (Which is a big WTF
column13: btw.) The problem is that at pixel sizes below 21px
column14: browsers apply the hinting embedded in the font
column15: which in FontAwesome 4.2 and up is just utterly
column16: utterly broken. This problem is **not limited to brand icons**. It affects all the icons in the set
column17: but is just more noticible on icons with intricate detail (like most brand icons...) than on others. You can
column18: infact
column19: work around the poor rendering fidelity due to the broken hinting by setting a css rotation small enough to remain visually undetectable
column20: but large enough to force the affected browsers (IE
column21: Firefox
column22: Chrome) to start rendering fonts with full sub-pixel geometric precision. Here\'s a snap of the **unfixed** icon in the searchbox on FontAwesome\'s own icon overview page
column23: as seen in Firefox on Windows 7 with Direct2D and DirectWrite enabled:![Unfixed]url  And here\'s the same
column24: with a added to the class via the developer tools:![Fixed]url  Notice the difference there?"'

column10: b"b' @rjgotten thanks for the very detailed infoany info on how Dave could fix this?'"

column11: you need hinting set up properly to get a font to render at subpixel position in Windows. If hinting is not present
column12: then as far as I know both DirectWrite and GDI ClearType will default to snapping towards the nearest whole pixel. This is what FontAwesome 4.2+ is currently doing
column13: I believe. Browsers rendering with DirectWrite have a hardcoded behavior to skip hinting tables altogether and render at full subpixel precision for font-sizes greater than 20 pixels. The rotation hack forces them to do the same with font-sizes of 20 pixels or smaller. However
column14: that does not fix the issue for browsers stuck with GDI ClearType
column15: which iirc does not have the same behavior of starting to render at full subpixel precision. I don\'t think there\'s a way around it: you _must_ have proper hinting tables to fix this completely.The good news is that having TTFAutoHint generate hinting works OK for most icons
column16: atleast given a cursory glance."'

column10: b'b" The Quartz rendering engine ignores hinting information baked into fonts and does its own thing. The fact that a font works OK on Macs means absolutely nothing. Infact
column11: I\'d go sofar as to say that the fact that many type designers never bothered inspecting their work outside of the safe little cushioned isle of their Macs
column12: is one of the leading causes for the absymal state of cross-platform rendering fidelity for many fonts currently available for use on the web.Windows 10 changed the rendering rules for DirectWrite
column13: iirc.That may include Microsoft having switched to a similar approach as Apple: ignore hinting always
column14: always rendering at full precision and do the subpixel handling yourself.That would probably be becaus in a basic Windows VM installation DirectWrite is _disabled_ due to lack of hardware support. Firefox then falls back to GDI rendering. The default behavior of GDI rendering in Windows applications is to adher to the OS setting for ClearType. And in most VM installs it will be _turned off_ by default. Hence all the jagged edges in Firefox on both the icon font and the normal text. IE though
column15: while it will also not have DirectWrite
column16: will by default override the OS level setting for ClearType and will render with ClearType _enabled_
column17: so in IE\'s case the normal text will be ok
column18: and only the icon font will be jaggy because the icon font is not properly hinted. (Sidenote: hinting is actually much more important for GDI rendering than it is for DirectWrite rendering.) Chrome will
column19: when DirectWrite is not available
column20: fall back to its own internal font renderer which
column21: if I remember correctly
column22: will render with full geometric precision when no hinting (or broken hinting
column23: or an unapplicable type of hinting) is present. So.. I guess you just delivered the evidence you were looking for that proves the hinting is broken?"'

column10: b'b" Figures... FYI; This is a long-standing issue with Webkit in general. Webkit doesn\'t obey instructions that go below some semi-arbitrary hardcoded set of lower limits
column11: which are picked based on the browser\'s configured default script. For western script this limit lies at 3 or 4 pixels
column12: while for most eastern asian scripts the lower limit lies at 10 to 12 pixels. Iirc
column13: this was put into Webkit in a gravely misguided effort to preserve text legibility
column14: which would explain why the asian scripts have an increased lower limit; increased glyph complexity requires a bigger minimum size to remain readable. (It sure doesn\'t explain the odd-ball 3px minimum for western script though. Even if you squint and have your eyes parked inches from your screen
column15: you still won\'t be able to tell what\'s written in such a small size...) This is also the root-cause of why the trick to align inline block elements doesn\'t work out of the box in Webkit and why it is so often fixed with a magic number of 4 pixel negative letter-spacing or word-spacing."'

column10: b"b' global .fa command is breaking custom icon sizes'"
b'b" The following two commands appear in _ and _
column11: and seem to be added in the latest version (4.2.0): .fa {  font: normal normal normal 14px/1 FontAwesome; // shortening font declaration  font-size: inherit; // can\'t have font-size inherit on line above
column12: so need to override} This combination of commands makes it impossible to override the font size without using the !important symbol.  For instance
column13: I have the following in my application: i { font-size: 22px; } which gets invalidated by the initial .fa code since they have the same CSS specificity
column14: and the FontAwesome SASS is included at the top of the file. To overcome this
column15: I have to change it to: .fa {  font-family: FontAwesome;} which allows me to set the custom font size without using the !important symbol. Since I\'m using bower to install FontAwesome
column16: this change can\'t be made on our production server
column17: which breaks all of our icon sizes. Could you please replace the commands with the one that I suggested
column18: so that you\'re not hard-coding the font size?"'

column11: sorry if I didn\\\'t get at 100% your issue... You want to change base icon size one for good
column12: am I right? And if you make something like you will break
column14: right? And this is why you are suggesting to go back to the old font declaration. Unfortunately we can\\\'t do this in a minor release because it will break backward compatibility. You could say "you already broke backward compatibility with this stuff!" and you are right
column15: sorry
column16: but that was not intended. The actual improved font declaration has some reasons and it is also used by octicons here: url  BTW I hacked with the development console to following fiddle: url  As far as i see
column17: overriding the tag will break the feature the same: ![screen shot 2014-12-04 at 13 00 54]url  So my suggestion is to add a variable to customize base font size
column18: something like  and set it to 14px. This will not break backward compatibility and will allow to customize the base font size
column19: **given that** fa-2x
column20: fa-3x will be related to container\\\'s font size and not base icon font size. At least we can multiply the base font size when generating classes and this makes sense
column21: but this need to be done in 5.0.0\''

column10: b'b\' I\\\'m glad you worked on this bug
column11: but I don\\\'t think you completely understood the issue. "You want to change base icon size one for good
column12: am I right?"No
column13: that is not what we\\\'re doing.  We don\\\'t want to set a base font size in FontAwesome for our entire project
column14: we want to specify a font size for individual icons on a case-by-case basis.  As an example
column15: here\\\'s what we\\\'re doing
column16: which has worked for many previous versions of FontAwesome: (I replaced "<" with "[" because GitHub won\\\'t render the HTML otherwise) HTML:[button class="select" onclick="..."]  [i class="fa fa-icon-glass"][/i][/button] CSS:button {  &.select {        &.fa-icon-glass {      &:before {        font-size: 18px;      }    }    }  }} With the addition of the following line in v4.2
column17: the custom font size specification as shown above no longer works: .fa {  font: normal normal normal 14px/1 FontAwesome; // shortening font declaration  font-size: inherit; // can\\\'t have font-size inherit on line above
column18: so need to override} The effect of this is that the previously working CSS commands shown above are ineffective
column19: and all of the FontAwesome icons remain the same size
column20: breaking backwards compatibility. The reason that this causes problems is
column21: that since you included the font size inside a single-line "font" command
column22: you have to issue a new "font" command in order to override it
column23: which means that everyone who upgrades to 4.2 has to inspect thousands of lines of SASS code and change all of the "font-size" commands to "font" commands
column25: and highly redundant (since FontAwesome needs to be specified over and over). I suggest changing it back to the v4.1 version
column26: which has the same effect of setting FontAwesome as the default font without hard-coding a font size into the "font" command.  It\\\'s not helpful to anyone that you\\\'re setting the base font size to 14px or any other size.  This should be determined by the natural CSS inheritance flow of the page
column27: not by a special FontAwesome variable. .fa {font-family: FontAwesome;// *\\\\* delete the font-size: inherit command
column28: it\\\'s unnecessary} Does that explain our issue better?\''

column10: b'b" This was not an intended change and we can\'t intentionally break backward compatibility. It could be done in 5.0.0 Could you please provide a couple of working fiddle that show the issue? You can start with these url  <-4.2url  <-4.1"'
b'b" The actual issue is when CSS specificity is
column11: in some circumstances
column12: being overridden by the global .fa command.  For instance
column13: when using the following CSS command to change font size in 4.1
column14: it works
column15: but in 4.2
column16: it doesn\'t: body   font-size: 22px;} Here are the fiddles to demonstrate the breakage: url  <-4.2url  <-4.1"'

column10: b'b" We\'ve moved to a shortened syntax
column11: which I\'m very happy with. For your particular issue
column12: is there a reason you can\'t just attach those sizes to instead of  ? Or even attach it to  ? That would be a more correct way to override classes in CSS and would solve your issue (I just tested this on your jsFiddle). Closing for now
column13: but happy to continue the discussion."'

column10: b'b\' It\\\'s a question of backward compatibility.  4.1 and below didn\\\'t require the use of a class to override
column11: and we have frozen at 4.1 because 4.2 would require us to go through thousands of lines of CSS in order to add an "&.fa { }" section.  We use object-oriented CSS which discourages the use of classes and instead relies on the inherent HTML structure for styling. Although the shortened syntax might appeal to someone who looks at the code and enjoys a minimal structure for the .fa { } section with a condensed "font" command
column12: in reality it breaks any overrides that were used in 4.1 and below for no real gain.\''

column10: b'b" @rob-clicktripz sorry but as I said this was an unintentional breaking change. I would suggest you to use the  version and override the class to meet your needsI\'m a little bit confused about this one... you said that OOCSS discourages the use of classes
column11: but in your example you have an tag with three classes plus one css rule to override the font size set on the tag itself url url  (no classes involved at all) Refers to #5198"'

column10: b'b\' "I\\\'m a little bit confused about this one... you said that OOCSS discourages the use of classes
column11: but in your example you have an [i] tag with three classes plus one css rule to override the font size set on the tag itself" I think there\\\'s a misunderstanding here:  OOCSS discourages the use of extraneous and unnecessary classes
column12: and instead relies on the inherent structure of the HTML for pinpointing commands.  So
column13: the only classes that should exist on the [i] element are the ones related to font-awesome
column14: which are "fa fa-history" (fa-44px was included for demonstration).  In order to override the global font command that you added in 4.2
column15: it becomes necessary to add another class to the [i] since the "body div What we\\\'re actually doing
column16: which worked with 4.1 and below
column17: is setting a custom font size on each [i] element in our application using the "font-size" command
column18: which can be different sizes according to its use on the page.  Because you\\\'re including this condensed "font" command with a hard-coded 14px
column19: along with a redundant "font-size: inherit" command (it\\\'s already inherited!)
column20: it forces us to add a class to the [i] in order to compete with the specificity of the ".fa" command. The actual issue is that you haven\\\'t improved anything in 4.2 by using this condensed font command (except that it looks cool)
column21: you\\\'ve only made it difficult to override the font-size.  If you look back to 4.1 (and below)
column22: the font command does not include a "font-size" command
column23: which allows the user to set their own font size without competing with the global ".fa" command. Here\\\'s the change again: 4.2:.fa {  font: normal normal normal 14px/1 FontAwesome; // shortening font declaration  font-size: inherit; // can\\\'t have font-size inherit on line above
column24: so need to override} replace with: 4.1:.fa {  font-family: FontAwesome;  font-style: normal;  font-weight: normal;} TLDR: Font Awesome shouldn\\\'t be setting a base font-size at all.  That should be left up to the web page
column26: and the user\\\'s stylesheets.  Your condensed font command
column28: causes specificity problems with user\\\'s stylesheets that have to compete with your "14px" and "inherit" font size commands.  Remove the font-size commands from the ".fa" section and all is well again (meaning that we can actually upgrade to 4.2 without breaking our application).\''

column11: as the width is slightly off you can see the label shift. The CSS trick actually already has a small margin we can use for similar situations but I think the problem might be in the sub pixel scale so while removing 1px on the letter-spacing from 10px to 9px helps it doesn\'t fully correct the effect. It would be awesome if you guys could redesign them to give more freedom to recombine icons. Regarding [fa-check-square-o]url  there isn\'t much to do and while I don\'t care much about it at the moment if the width delta to the others was a natural number it would be easy to hide by adjusting the letter-spacing. column10: b"b' I know this is a very old post but the solution is to reset the IE11 options by going to:  Tools > Then click on the Reset button as shown in this picture:  ![reset-button]url  I had the same problem when working on version 4.70 where all other browsers displayed correctly except IE11 on Windows 10 (1703  15063.502) and so I decided to to use the reset button and voila the icons appeared automatically.  You might need to restart the IE but try it anyway.  Hope this helps to some people who are still struggling with this.  Also
column11: clients need to reset their options if they complain of icons not displaying.  this should be the first thing to do before doing anything.  Me thinks so anyway.  '"

column11: icon-road-barrier
column12: icon-construction-barrier A construction barrier could have a few use cases.Most frequently
column13: it would probably be used to indicate "under construction" as an icon
column14: this might mean a link to a prototype part of an application or a link that an automated system has detected is broken for many users. In other scenarios
column15: a "road barrier" could carry the meaning "Warning"
column16: Detour
column17: Rough Travel Ahead
column18:
Access Denied" or any other of many cautionary meanings. Examples:**Warning**: [fa-barrier] "Click here for the advanced steps (requires Unix terminal experience)."**Detour**: [fa-barrier] "Temporarily Unavailable. Please use [Y] instead."**Rough Travel Ahead**: [fa-barrier] "This section is not for the faint of heart."**Access Denied**: [fa-barrier] "Your account has been denied access to this action. Please contact your administrator to determine why." Here are some B&W images, but I don\\\'t think they have the right feel: ![12-512]url ![1239167-clipart-of-a-black-and-white-road-block-construction-barrier-royalty-free-vector-illustration]url ![outlined-construction-barrier_gg71534247]url  The following color images capture what I think of when I think of "Construction Barrier":![depositphotos_5428100-under-construction-barrier]url ![construction_barrier]url \''

column10: b"b' Request to reopen A filing cabinet and Archive serve separate functions. A Filing cabinet is where you keep information and documents that are important and that you need at that point in time. When that information is old and no longer needs to live within that filing cabinet and take up that space but is important enough to keep
column11: you then archive it so it is accessible but not taking up space within your cabinet. '"

column10: b"b' Bullet Proof font-face syntax not so correct'"

b'b\' The bullet proof font-face syntax downloads eot for IE 11 when it should actually be downloading woff. The most accurate font-face syntax is with eot as source in the first line (no "fix") and the src in the next line starting with local(\\\'FontAwesome\\\')\''

column11: thanks for this report.  IE11 wasn\'t released when the original bullet proof syntax was proposed (2010). Unfortunately
column12: we must provide compatibility from IE8+ so we can\'t drop the format.  It would be interesting to check if the [BrowserStack]url  tool could help us in providing an up to date bullet proof font face syntax for modern browsers  This issue is strictly related to #10470
column13: I would keep discussing this there
column14: so please share your thoughts there  edit: rethought
column15: let\'s keep this open too"'

column10: b'b" Not asking for removal of IE 8 support. All for keeping it. The correct syntax is in which the second line has a local(\'FontAwesome\')
column11: as the first thing for src and immediately followed by woff2. Eot appears in the src in the first line. "'

column10: b"b' @vijayaraghavanramanan are you referrig to this: url  ?'"

column11: the smiley is not necessary. Local-anything will do. But to prevent clashes with locally installed font names or for the case where local fonts may be an old version
column12: smiley is better. "'

column10: b'b" Problem is: we cannot use FontAwesome to avoid conflict with older version
column11: as you said.  Also: the date of the post should be 5th May 2010
column12: but we have this note here: url  I\'ve just checked FontSquirrel\'s generator and it still uses fontawesome\'s approach.  It is definitely interesting improve the font face declaration but we should know each side effect we could run into"'

column10: b'b" What I actually meant about old version is this: suppose I use local(\'FontAwesome\') and some browser user has Font Awesome installed locally on  machine and it\'s not updated. Then new icons may not appear. But that still leaves the smiley option open and should work. Needs some tests I\'d agree with that. Maybe would should ask Paul Irish. I think he may not be aware that IE11 loads the eot instead of woff. "'

column10: b'b\' The code is there to improve performance. (Or to schedule the changes for icon replacements when it\\\'s convenient for the browser). It separates the changes that are needed from the changes occurring. This keeps the "jank" at a minimum as we render icons.  While this works pretty well in most cases I can understand this asynchronous operation creates a flash of changing content for Turbolinks. So
column11: the best way to address this is add a configuration option that forces these operations (the mutations to the DOM) to be performed immediately.  Let me take a look at how much effort this is going to be.\''
this wasn\'t difficult to implement and we\'ll have a new config option that can control how the engine replaces icons. This will be included in 5.8.0."'

column11: I have watched FA5 grow and evolve into the stunning icon library that it now is
column12: but until now I haven\'t had a chance to use it for any projects (long and boring reasons). That being said
column13: I have noticed that the NPM implementation doesn\'t work the way the documentation says it should. I have messed around with it for a while now and am pretty sure the implementation has changed without the docs being updated.  So here goes nothing... as per the docs we are expected to use something like the below.   This is all good and well but the method only accepts an array of icons which is the implementation I\'ve used below.   My way works perfectly and I\'ll explain why. Using the documented method yields only one icon for use
column14: from what I\'ve seen while debugging the compiled code any new icon overwrites the last one in an endless cycle which isn\'t fun.  As mentioned
column15: I\'ve been testing this for quite a while now and am pretty sure it\'s a simple disconnect between the NPM package and the documentation. For reference
column16: I\'m using the below packages which are all up-to-date.   Hopefully
column17: it\'s just a minor thing as FA5 is beautiful
column18: elegant and extremely simple to integrate.  Thanks for reading \\xf0\\x9f\\x98\\x84."'

b'b" OK!  So far with further debugging I have found that is working as designed. Cool! What I also found is that the Babel build I have running is causing a recursive loop of some kind when is enabled.  What happens is the I also set up a project in codesandbox too and it worked which still doesn\'t tell me why my local build doesn\'t work correctly.  All that said
column11: I\'m doubting this is an issue with my local build script as I\'ve tried getting it set up with both Babel 6&7 but to no avail
column12: the same behaviour applies. I\'m at a loss simply because this is the only script misbehaving in the JS source I\'m building."'

column11: After integrating some logs in a local copy of the ES source I finally tracked the issue down and I believe it is a legitimate one. What I found is when the hook runs
column12: it automatically calls upon the function which attempts to inject the SVG into the DOM. The injection functionality is working but what happens is this.  1. The core library is completely loaded when the page load which means all elements are available for it to find and use 2. I add an icon to the library which runs again 3. I add another icon
column13: but because the first addition runs
column14: the DOM element is no longer available for the library to use  I believe this is a basic oversight and that DOM elements without a matching library definition shouldn\'t be manipulated in any way.  Hope that helps explains the issue in more detail."'

column11: I gotcha. I\'ve confirmed the underlying issue with a test case. We\'ll get this fix in the queue."'

column10: b'b" Fair enough for the home page
column11: which could be a link to the project as a whole and updating it is valid.  But doing so for the icons page
column12: and especially specific icons
column13: effectively breaks **every** existing link to those pages. Because anyone linking to the icons page or a specific icon of *must* be expecting 4.7
column14: and none of the 5.0 icon classes will work on 4.7.  This is not beneficial for anyone old projects now have broken links
column15: and you now likely have people with no clue what\'s going on getting redirected to a broken icon list. Because
column16: to 4.7 users
column17: the 5.0 icon list is broken. You might be hoping this encourages people to upgrade but the people visiting these links likely have no control over the version they are using and won\'t have a clue why it\'s not working.  We\'ve already updated the links we\'re aware of in our projects. But I\'m concerned about other projects
column18: including at least one large framework
column19: that now have broken links that are not feasible to update yet trivially fixed here by adjusting a redirect.  Sure
column20: leave the home page redirecting to the new one. But
column21: please
column22: at least preserve links to the old content via redirect of the path and subpaths."'

column10: b"b' Massive problems using FontAwesome Pro 5.3.1 TTF fonts in PowerPoint'"

b'b" ### Describe the problem  Installing FontAwesome TTF fonts results in verious problems using any product: Main Problem: The internal font naming in TTF obviously creates a complete mismatch as in PowerPoint these different fonts are neither shown as different fonts nor as different font styles of the same base font. In addition most glyphs of FontAwesome Pro cannot be selected! They don\'t appear at all.  ### What did you expect? No problems at all and reaching all glyphs Using TTF is essential because OTF fonts cannot be embedded in PowerPoint files. Aren\'t TTF fonts tested or only a conversion of OTF fonts. The bugs with TTF seem to are so heavy that usage in our team is not reliable and I have to withdraw the TTF fonts.  We\'ll have to test OTF types first tests show a much better handling but still problems with some import filters which do not transfer all code points from Font Awesome 5 Pro for example (Word import into FrameMaker)  ### What version and implementation are you using? 5.3.1 Pleas find attached a PPTX test file [FA ]url   "'

column12: although they do appear in the \'add symbol\' dialog in PowerPoint. These icons also work fine with MS Word. Is there\'s any workaround or solution for this?"'

column10: b"b' We finally switched from TTF to OTF (both refer to the extension of filenames) and this worked for us. Be aware this is not OpenType vs. TrueType because both are OpenType. OTF is Adobe Technology and TTF is Microsoft technology and refers only to the internal glyph definitions) to be able to use all the symbols.  As far as I understand the font naming in TTF fonts of FA has not been the way PowerPoint expects it. In OTF fonts font naming seems to be ok for PowerPoint. But keep in mind that you cannot embed the symbols from OTF fonts in PowerPoint this is only works with TTF fonts. I did not check the current version 5.6.1 with TTF but OTF seems to work in Powerpoint.'"
b"b' @DieterGust thanks.  @yhacohen please make sure you are using the .otf files on desktop. If you still have issues
column11: please open a new issue filling out our [bug report template]url ttf files are optimized for the web and for legacy browsers '"

column10: b'b\' @tagliayou said: "TTF files are optimized for the web and for legacy browser".  Well for Microsoft systems and products you should use TTF fonts only this is official Microsoft policy. Microsoft always tries to skip font support for fonts using extension .otf
column11: so Adobe always has to remember Microsoft to accept this this extension of OpenType  .otf refers to Adobe technology inside the TTF-based OpentType technology.  So I don\\\'t understand your preference of OTF. Ligatures are not a use case for Symbol fonts
column12: or am I wrong? And TTF is the real the basis of the OpenType technology
column13: so OpenType fonts with .ttf extension fonts should behave the same as fonts with .otf extension otherwise there is something wrong with the implemented internal font technology.\''

column11: sorry if I didn\'t provide enough details. The TTF files are generated by the webfont generator
column12: and those specific ttf files are not guaranteed to work on desktop.  We could definitely try to provide proper desktop-ready TTF files alongside OTF files
column13: but it is another feature to manage and maintain Ligatures are helpful on the desktop because you can do something like this  ![output]url Ref: url "'

b"b' Hi currently you have a lot of magnifying glass search icons
column11: but they all face left. Would it be possible to have some right facing ones also?'"

column10: b"b' Hi!  Thanks for being part of the Font Awesome Community.  You can take advantage of and  url  url CSS: url  SVG (rotate): url  SVG (power transform): url Hope it helps  Closing here'"
b"b' Hi so for Desktop you just have to manually rotate it yourself?  I understand not duplicating many of the icons for this kind of thing
column11: but there seems 2 different purposes for these icons
column12: so would it not make sense to have both? Like you have a left and a right arrow?  In the instances of using it for Search
column13: they appear to be mostly facing right. For Zoom it seems to face the other way. Would it not make sense to have 2 different icons for these reasons?'"

column11: I will reopen this request but please let me share some personal thoughts. Sorry
column12: didn\'t get that this was for desktop. I think that having rotated icons would help on some desktop applications. Anyway
column13: we have a [new icon request template]url  and we ask for a use case: specifying that it was far desktop would have been helpful. I think that there are functional differences between arrows pointing in different directions. If I must do a comparison
column14: I see this as a request for a [broom]url  with the handle in the opposite way: it does not change the functionality of the icon. I think that delegating the direction of the handle to different functionalities in the same UI is not a good idea.  If I have to show an icon for search and another one for zoom in the same toolbar
column15: I would go for [search]url  and [search-plus]url  "'

column10: b'b" Thanks for getting back to me.  I was only going off real world examples. Microsoft always seem to have search facing right. I don\'t think it is similar to something like a broom because the search icon is a major part of all user interfaces and used in such a particular way. If I was using a Broom I would have no preference in which way it faced.  I was just trying to find where I would see the symbol the other way
column11: and in something like Microsoft Word it denotes Zoom
column12: and not Search Plus
column13: because that denotes Zoom in. It is not ideal having such a similar image but I think that is all there would be. This isn\'t an issue for our application."'
